p: The long-lasting and consistent use of C. coggygria in traditional medicine across countries offers a sound base for its therapeutic use. However, data on the pharmacology of C. coggygria extracts are, for now, at a rather basic stage. Among explored properties, the anti-inflammatory effect was the first to attract the attention of researchers and to be tested experimentally ( Bezruk and Lyubetskaya, 1969). Extracts obtained from both leaves and heartwood reduced inflammation in rodent models, while the water extract inhibited cyclooxygenases -1 and -2 ( Table 1).
